EXISTING STRUCTURES
─────────────────────────────
### Shared Smelting Furnaces Automation Network
Consists of:
• Two stone furnaces – one at Position(x=0.0, y=0.0) and another at Position(x=5.0, y=0.0) – each paired with nearby burner inserters and output chests.
• Interconnecting transport belts that route materials between furnaces and adjacent logistics components.

### Iron Ore Mining Automation Setup
Consists of:
• A burner mining drill at Position(x=-15.0, y=-50.0) equipped with associated burner inserters and a wooden chest (for example, at Position(x=-13.5, y=-51.5)).
• Transport belt links that convey the mined iron ore from the drill to processing areas.

### Automation Research Lab
Consists of:
• A laboratory structure receiving automation-science-pack inputs (currently in a no-power state).
• A supporting network of small electric poles that interconnects the lab with available power sources.

### Water Supply System for Power Generation with Updated Steam Engine Placement
Consists of:
• A boiler at Position(x=8.0, y=20.5) featuring connection points at Position(x=8.5, y=18.5) and Position(x=8.5, y=22.5); its fluid box holds 200 units of water at 15° C.
• A series of steam engines (generators) intended for power generation:
  – Pre‐existing steam engine at Position(x=1.5, y=13.5)
  – Pre‐existing steam engine at Position(x=13.5, y=14.5)
  – Pre‐existing steam engine at Position(x=19.5, y=14.5)
  – Pre‐existing steam engine at Position(x=13.5, y=17.5)
  – Pre‐existing steam engine at Position(x=17.5, y=20.5)
  – Pre‐existing steam engine at Position(x=11.5, y=20.5)
  – Newly placed steam engine at Position(x=22.5, y=18.5) (successfully set in Step 397 with orientation UP)
• An offshore pump at Position(x=0.5, y=30.5) that supplies water to the system.
• Multiple pipe groups interconnecting the boiler, steam engines, and pump.
• Note: Although the new steam engine was ultimately placed at (22.5, y≈18.5), repeated placement attempts closer to the boiler failed and the current misalignment has led to persistent pipe connection errors.

ERROR TIPS
────────────
• Steam Engine Placement Failures
 – Repeated errors occurred when attempting to place the newly crafted steam engine at candidate coordinates such as (9.0, 17.5), (3.0, 10.0), (10.5, 17.5) and via using place_entity_next_to (with direction UP). The failures were due to collisions with existing entities or unplaceable terrain (notably water).
 – Tip: Validate candidate coordinates using buildability checks and bounding box feedback. Consider alternative directions or increased spacing to avoid collisions and terrain obstructions.

• Pipe Connection Errors
 – Multiple attempts to pipe-connect the boiler (at Position(x=8.0, y=20.5)) to the steam engine (at Position(x=22.5, y=18.5)) failed—errors indicated an inability to determine the required pipe count and connect the entities.
 – Tip: Ensure that the relative placement of entities permits seamless alignment of connection points. Reposition components or clear blocking entities to facilitate proper fluid system integration.

• Use of Placement APIs
 – Error messages stating “Could not place steam-engine” indicate that the placement function rejected the target location due to obstructions or collision with existing terrain (e.g., water).
 – Tip: Perform pre-placement clearance and collision checks before issuing placement commands, and adjust target positions based on environmental constraints.
